examples.title: German Vocabulary - Urteil
examples.back_mnemonics:
Cognate with English 'ordeal', from Proto-Germanic *uʀdailijan, ('to mete out or allot'),
      from *uʀ + *dailijan, 'to deal out, divide'). Histoically an 'ordeal' (precarious situation, e.g. drowning) was a form of judgement (by God).

examples.title: Thanking in Advance
examples.front_question_text: Vielen Dank im Voraus für Ihre Mühe.
examples.back_answer: Thank you in advance for your effort.
examples.back_explanation: A common and polite phrase to express gratitude for anticipated help or effort.

examples.title: Spanish Preterite - To Speak
examples.front_question_text: How do you say 'I spoke' in Spanish?
examples.front_question_context: Using the verb 'hablar' in preterite tense
examples.front_question_example: Ayer _____ con mi madre. (Yesterday I spoke with my mother)
examples.back_explanation: Preterite form of 'hablar' for first person singular. Regular -ar verbs in preterite end in -é for 'yo'.
examples.back_mnemonics: AR verbs: é, aste, ó, amos, asteis, aron

examples.title: French Greeting - Good Morning
examples.back_explanation: Standard French greeting used from morning until late afternoon. More formal than 'salut'.

examples.title: Second Conditional Structure
examples.front_question_text: Complete the second conditional: If I _____ rich, I _____ buy a house.
examples.front_question_hint: Use past tense in if-clause, would + infinitive in main clause
examples.back_explanation: Second conditional structure: If + past simple, would + infinitive. Uses 'were' for all persons with the verb 'be'.
